trans-unit.source: Removing Objects from the Pipeline Where Object
trans-unit.target: Removing Objects from the Pipeline Where Object

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell, you often generate and pass along more objects to a pipeline than you want.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell, you often generate and pass along more objects to a pipeline than you want.

trans-unit.source: You can specify the properties of particular objects to display by using the **Format** cmdlets, but this does not help with the problem of removing entire objects from the display.
trans-unit.target: You can specify the properties of particular objects to display by using the **Format** cmdlets, but this does not help with the problem of removing entire objects from the display.

trans-unit.source: You may want to filter objects before the end of a pipeline, so you can perform actions on only a subset of the initially-generated objects.
trans-unit.target: You may want to filter objects before the end of a pipeline, so you can perform actions on only a subset of the initially-generated objects.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell includes a **Where-Object** cmdlet that allows you to test each object in the pipeline and only pass it along the pipeline if it meets a particular test condition.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell includes a **Where-Object** cmdlet that allows you to test each object in the pipeline and only pass it along the pipeline if it meets a particular test condition.

trans-unit.source: Objects that do not pass the test are removed from the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Objects that do not pass the test are removed from the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: You supply the test condition as the value of the **Where-ObjectFilterScript** parameter.
trans-unit.target: You supply the test condition as the value of the **Where-ObjectFilterScript** parameter.

trans-unit.source: The value of **FilterScript** is a *script block* - one or more Windows PowerShell commands surrounded by braces {} - that evaluates to true or false.
trans-unit.target: The value of **FilterScript** is a *script block* - one or more Windows PowerShell commands surrounded by braces {} - that evaluates to true or false.

trans-unit.source: These script blocks can be very simple, but creating them requires knowing about another Windows PowerShell concept, comparison operators.
trans-unit.target: These script blocks can be very simple, but creating them requires knowing about another Windows PowerShell concept, comparison operators.

trans-unit.source: A comparison operator compares the items that appear on each side of it.
trans-unit.target: A comparison operator compares the items that appear on each side of it.

trans-unit.source: Comparison operators begin with a '-' character and are followed by a name.
trans-unit.target: Comparison operators begin with a '-' character and are followed by a name.

trans-unit.source: Basic comparison operators work on almost any kind of object.
trans-unit.target: Basic comparison operators work on almost any kind of object.

trans-unit.source: The more advanced comparison operators might only work on text or arrays.
trans-unit.target: The more advanced comparison operators might only work on text or arrays.

trans-unit.source: By default, when working with text, Windows PowerShell comparison operators are case-insensitive.
trans-unit.target: By default, when working with text, Windows PowerShell comparison operators are case-insensitive.

trans-unit.source: Due to parsing considerations, symbols such as <,>, and = are not used as comparison operators.
trans-unit.target: Due to parsing considerations, symbols such as <,>, and = are not used as comparison operators.

trans-unit.source: Instead, comparison operators are comprised of letters.
trans-unit.target: Instead, comparison operators are comprised of letters.

trans-unit.source: The basic comparison operators are listed in the following table.
trans-unit.target: The basic comparison operators are listed in the following table.

trans-unit.source: Is less than or equal to
trans-unit.target: Is less than or equal to

trans-unit.source: Is greater than or equal to
trans-unit.target: Is greater than or equal to

trans-unit.source: Is not like (wildcard comparison for text)
trans-unit.target: Is not like (wildcard comparison for text)

trans-unit.source: Where-Object script blocks use the special variable '$_' to refer to the current object in the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Where-Object script blocks use the special variable '$_' to refer to the current object in the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of how it works.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of how it works.

trans-unit.source: If you have a list of numbers, and only want to return the ones that are less than 3, you can use Where-Object to filter the numbers by typing:
trans-unit.target: If you have a list of numbers, and only want to return the ones that are less than 3, you can use Where-Object to filter the numbers by typing:

trans-unit.source: Since $_ refers to the current pipeline object, we can access its properties for our tests.
trans-unit.target: Since $_ refers to the current pipeline object, we can access its properties for our tests.

trans-unit.source: As an example, we can look at the Win32_SystemDriver class in WMI.
trans-unit.target: As an example, we can look at the Win32_SystemDriver class in WMI.

trans-unit.source: There might be hundreds of system drivers on a particular system, but you might only be interested in a particular set of the system drivers, such as those which are currently running.
trans-unit.target: There might be hundreds of system drivers on a particular system, but you might only be interested in a particular set of the system drivers, such as those which are currently running.

trans-unit.source: If you use Get-Member to view Win32_SystemDriver members (**Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_SystemDriver | Get-Member -MemberType Property**) you will see that the relevant property is State, and that it has a value of "Running" when the driver is running.
trans-unit.target: If you use Get-Member to view Win32_SystemDriver members (**Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_SystemDriver | Get-Member -MemberType Property**) you will see that the relevant property is State, and that it has a value of "Running" when the driver is running.

trans-unit.source: You can filter the system drivers, selecting only the running ones by typing:
trans-unit.target: You can filter the system drivers, selecting only the running ones by typing:

trans-unit.source: This still produces a long list.
trans-unit.target: This still produces a long list.

trans-unit.source: You may want to filter to only select the drivers set to start automatically by testing the StartMode value as well:
trans-unit.target: You may want to filter to only select the drivers set to start automatically by testing the StartMode value as well:

trans-unit.source: This gives us a lot of information we no longer need because we know that the drivers are running.
trans-unit.target: This gives us a lot of information we no longer need because we know that the drivers are running.

trans-unit.source: In fact, the only information we probably need at this point are the name and the display name.
trans-unit.target: In fact, the only information we probably need at this point are the name and the display name.

trans-unit.source: The following command includes only those two properties, resulting in much simpler output:
trans-unit.target: The following command includes only those two properties, resulting in much simpler output:

trans-unit.source: There are two Where-Object elements in the above command, but they can be expressed in a single Where-Object element by using the -and logical operator, like this:
trans-unit.target: There are two Where-Object elements in the above command, but they can be expressed in a single Where-Object element by using the -and logical operator, like this:

trans-unit.source: The standard logical operators are listed in the following table.
trans-unit.target: The standard logical operators are listed in the following table.

trans-unit.source: Logical and; true if both sides are true
trans-unit.target: Logical and; true if both sides are true

trans-unit.source: Logical or; true if either side is true
trans-unit.target: Logical or; true if either side is true

trans-unit.source: Logical not; reverses true and false
trans-unit.target: Logical not; reverses true and false

trans-unit.source: Logical not; reverses true and false
trans-unit.target: Logical not; reverses true and false
